subject: Re: [junit] Custom Test Suite...
msgSnippet: I think I wrote this up in another message in this group. You should be able to adapt the solution to your situation. The message subject was Dynamically
messageBody:
I think I wrote this up in another message in this group. You should be
able to adapt the solution to your situation.

The message subject was "Dynamically generating test methods?". There
may be more than one.

Take care.

So said Mark Derricutt on 2/14/2003 --------------------

>Hiya, having just started a new job, as way of getting my head around
>some
>of the code, I was asked to write some unit tests, and after writing a
>heap
>of them, I noticed that the test itself was always the same, which
just
>different settings.
>
>I was also told that they'd like our testing guy to be able to make up
new
>tests on the fly, so I wrote a new test which loaded an XML file,
which
>took care of defining what I wanted to test for, and get back. The
test
>code looks like this:
>
> public void testUnmarshelledMessage() {
>
> try {
> File path = new File("/home/mark/testmessages");
> File[] files = path.listFiles();
>
> for (int i = 0; i < files.length; i++) {
> File file = files[i];
> if ( file.getName().startsWith("test") &&
>file.getName().endsWith("xml")) {
> Reader reader = new FileReader(
file.getAbsoluteFile()
>);
> TestMessage testMessage = (TestMessage)
readObject(
>reader );
> MessageStatus result = sender.send(
>testMessage.getMessage() );
> assertEquals( file.getName() + "(" +
>testMessage.getName() + ")",
> testMessage.getResult(),
result.getStatusCode() );
> }
> }
> } catch ( Exception e ) {
> fail( e.getMessage() );
> }
>
> }
>
>So the test finds all files starting with test and ending with xml in
the
>specified directory, calls readObject() to unmarshall the XML file
into my
>TestMessage object, and does the test, and checks the result. This is
all
>working nicely, untill I wrote a test that failed.
>
>Because this test is just that, one test, once it failed, none of the
>other
>XML files got processed. So I've been trying to think of a way around
it,
>a way to run my test method against each XML file as its own test.
>
>I had thought of writing a custom TestSuite which took the path, found
the
>files, and added a custom TestCase with the filename ( instead of
method
>name ), and moving the actual test code above into the custom
TestCase,
>however I'm not quite sure the best way to implement this.
>
>Any ideas?
>
>Mark
